Our window to understanding autism (''New Theories Help Explain Mysteries of Autism,'' Dec. 28) is Fragile X Syndrome, the most common inherited cause of mental retardation. Many people affected by Fragile X display some autistic-like symptoms, like poor eye contact, hand flapping and hand biting.

In some cases of Fragile X, the autistic-like symptoms are so pronounced that the individual's primary diagnosis is autism; some 5 to 10 percent of males with autism test positive for Fragile X. It is caused by mutation of a single gene (FMR1) on the X chromosome; the mutated gene fails to make the protein FMRP. The function of this protein, and how its lack causes the Fragile X symptoms, is the subject of active research today.
DR. MARTIN H. ISRAEL St. Louis
